moves.1. d4: Solid, and usually leading to slow play.
moves.2... e5: The Budapest Gambit, a relatively new opening at the time.
moves.3. dxe5: The automatic response, then and now.
moves.3... Ne4: A rarer variant is 3... N-N5, threatening to win back the Pawn at once.
moves.4. a3: To prevent a Black minor piece from occupying QN5.
moves.4... d6: Opening a line for the QB and threatening to recapture the gambited Pawn.
moves.5. exd6: To preserve his material advantage, White consents to the exchange.
moves.5... Bxd6: Now Black has a considerable advantage in development and a centralized Knight in return for the Pawn.
moves.6. g3: The game-losing blunder. 6 B-Q2, 6 N-Q2 or 6 N-KR3 would all have prevented Black's winning tactical maneuver.
moves.6... Nxf2: Decisive. If the Q moves away, Black wins the Exchange with 7... NxR. If 7 KxN, 7... BxP ch wins the White Q. Warren of course resigns at once.
